bestBHT.bht: A corrupt tree is incapable of bearing good fruit, but it can transform and produce good fruit. This verse counters the belief in man's ability to perform good deeds solely through his willpower. It emphasizes that our deeds are a reflection of our moral nature. Just as a good tree naturally yields good fruit, a person with a righteous character will naturally produce beneficial actions. The goodness of the tree determines the quality of its fruit, and similarly, a preacher's doctrines align with their moral character.

Henry Alford: A bad tree then cannot bear good fruit: but it may, from bad, become good, in order to the bearing good fruit.

These verses were his weapon against the shallow Pelagian scheme, which would look at men’s deeds apart from the living root in man out of which they grew, and suppose that man’s unaided will is capable of good.
It is entirely contrary to the whole scope of the passage.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 17. Even so every good tree bringeth
forth good fruit: but a corrupt tree bringeth forth evil fruit.
Albert Barnes: A corrupt tree does not signify... that the tree 'had been' good, but had become 'vitiated;'"
it was a tree of a useless character
a nature that produced nothing beneficial
Philip Schaff: As the tree, so is the fruit. The principle holds good in the moral world.
Every good tree, i.e., of a good nature for bearing fruit.
Our Lord applies the general law to men’s actions and their moral results; these are but manifestations of a moral nature, depraved or sanctified.
John Gill: The tree that brings forth good fruit, is good antecedent to the fruit it produces; it is first good, and then puts forth good fruit.
It is not the fruit that makes the tree good, but makes it appear to be so; but it is the goodness of the tree that makes the fruit good.
If the tree is corrupt, the fruit will be corrupt; and as is the preacher, so will be his doctrines.

bhtAttempts.bht: A bad tree cannot bear good fruit, but it has the potential to become good and produce good fruit. This verse is a rebuttal against the belief that man's unaided will can produce good deeds; it emphasizes the importance of the root from which our actions grow. Just as a good tree naturally produces good fruit, so too does a morally upright nature lead to beneficial actions. It is the inherent goodness of the tree that determines the quality of its fruit, not the other way around. Similarly, the character of a preacher will be reflected in the doctrines they proclaim.

A corrupt tree cannot bear good fruit, but it has the potential to change and produce good fruit. This passage refutes the belief in Pelagianism, highlighting that our actions are rooted in our moral nature. As a good tree naturally yields good fruit, a person with a righteous character will produce beneficial deeds. The quality of one's actions stems from the goodness within. Just as the nature of a tree determines the quality of its fruit, the character of a preacher influences the doctrines they preach.

A corrupt tree is incapable of bearing good fruit, but it can transform and produce good fruit. This verse counters the belief in man's ability to perform good deeds solely through his willpower. It emphasizes that our deeds are a reflection of our moral nature. Just as a good tree naturally yields good fruit, a person with a righteous character will naturally produce beneficial actions. The goodness of the tree determines the quality of its fruit, and similarly, a preacher's doctrines align with their moral character.

A bad tree cannot bear good fruit, but it possesses the potential to become good and produce beneficial fruit. This passage dismantles the notion of the self-sufficiency of man's will in producing virtuous deeds. It reaffirms that our actions are rooted in our moral nature. Just as a good tree naturally yields good fruit, a person with a righteous character will naturally produce worthwhile deeds. The quality of one's actions is determined by the inherent goodness within them, not the other way around. Similarly, a preacher's doctrines reflect their moral character.

A corrupt tree cannot bear good fruit, but it has the potential to change and produce good fruit. This verse counters the belief that man's will alone can produce virtuous deeds. It emphasizes the significance of the root from which our actions emerge. Just as a good tree naturally yields good fruit, a person with a righteous character will naturally produce beneficial actions. The quality of our deeds reflects the goodness or corruption within us. Likewise, a preacher's doctrines are influenced by their moral nature.
